item.title: I gotta eat humble pie
item.description: https://www.wired.com/story/why-car-brands-are-finally-switching-back-to-buttons/ 2 ish years ago, I got my electric car with the touch screen only controls. It was great at first, set it and forget it type of deal. That new car feeling died pretty fucking fast when my touchscreen froze in the middle of summer. The touchscreen lag drives me fucking insane on cold days, IS THE TEMPERATURE SET OR NOT?!? Guess we’ll drive ~3 miles before we find out. I was/am an idiot and no one should listen to me. I was wrong about touchscreens in cars.

item.title: James "Jim" Moylan, inventor of the gas tank arrow.
item.description: Artificial hearts, great. Particle accelerator, fantastic. Silicon wafer deposition, outstanding. Brilliant people and groups uraveling the secrets of the universe, moving humanity forward in great leaps. But let us not go without celebrating the inventors out there, toiling away in anonymity, making large numbers of people's lives just a little bit better or easier everyday. Jim Moylan is the legend that came up with the little arrow that tells you which side your gas cap is on. Those of us that drove cars without them back in the day, can fully appreciate his idea. Anyone who's pulled a rental car into a gas station on a cold, rainy night, tired, hungry, and homesick, got out to fuel up, only find out you need to get back in, do a 13 point turn in the tiny lot so the gas cap is facing the pump, and then get back out into the howling wind to get gas, owes you a debt of gratitude for saving us just that little bit of hassle that ads to the list of small indignities that compound into miserable day. Who among us can know how many "straw that broke the camel's back" moments were prevented by Jim. No doubt, many underpaid hotel desk clerks, fast food workers and gas station attendants didn't get snapped at because the driver wasn't finally pushed over the edge by "one more goddammed thing". Fewer fingers given and spouses barked at. Thank you Jim. Hall of Legends: Jim Moylan Whoever said "hey, lets print the tag in a t-shirt" instead of sewing an itchy one in. Dr. Spencer Silver and Art Fry, without whom we would have to find a piece of paper AND tape to put a note. Daniel F. Cudzik, the patent holder for the "stay on tab" that replaced the pull tabs on beverage cans responsible for countless chokings, maimed animals, litter and Jimmy Buffets injured foot. etc. etc. etc.

item.description: https://www.texastribune.org/2025/12/24/south-texas-ice-arrests-home-construction/ It’s not like they are sending masked gunmen to snatch workers from their jobs, or creating a terror campaign that is forcing brown people to stay in their homes, or raiding businesses without proper warrants in place, or arresting/deporting citizens including US veterans to countries they have never been to, or operating detention centers that violate human rights and deny them basic dignity, or explicitly telling their voters that America’s true destiny is to become a White Christian nation. Nah, I’m sure these people in south Texas are just overreacting to a standard US govt operation of kidnapping non white people. Plus, I’m pretty sure they can write a strongly worded letter if things get out of hand.

26 Imgur Creator Spotlight: @huleeb did this. I love it. Check out their ton of other artwork and give them some love.
27 Man Tax: Anthony Joshua
“Tragedy blows through your life like a tornado, uprooting everything, creating chaos. You wait for the dust to settle, and then you choose. You can live in the wreckage and pretend it's still the mansion you remember. Or you can crawl from the rubble and slowly rebuild.” - Veronica Mars I try to keep my posts "good vibe zones". So, instead of finding the one thing in here you don't like and commenting only on that, also comment about something you DID like. Balance the negativity. Love you long time. So, I made a discord server. It's a relaxed environment where you can take/donate memes to the cause, play trivia twice a week, chat about lots of topics or about nothing at all. We also have Jack Box game night and are setting up movie night! Very laid back/relaxed vibe. Come hang with us. https://discord.gg/AWFV7FT3RQ I'm also on the imgcat server for updates & fun: https://discord.gg/TpjD37jgJ9 ***Also if you miss abbiistabbii's discord community good news! Here's the new one https://discord.gg/NPStJGgARq - where everyone's reconnecting, shitposting, and hanging out again*** https://ko-fi.com/mememuseumcurator Unable to work, zero income. Feel free to leave me a tip. Those that have, y'all are the bee's knees. You've helped me so much. ***Tag me if you see an artist/creator you like whose work isn't getting seen as much as it should be! Or if you are an artist/creator and want me to post something of yours, DM me!
item.dc:creator: MemeMuseumCurator

item.title: For your slow Sunday.
item.description: I have already intimated to you, the danger of parties in the state, with particular reference to the founding of them on geographical discriminations. Let me now take a more comprehensive view, and warn you in the most solemn manner against the baneful effects of the spirit of party generally. This spirit, unfortunately, is inseparable from our nature, having its root in the strongest passions of the human mind. It exists under different shapes in all governments more or less stifled, controlled, or repressed; but in those of the popular form, it is seen in its greatest rankness and is truly their worst enemy. The alternate domination of one faction over another, sharpened by the spirit of revenge, natural to party dissention, which in different ages and countries has perpetrated the most horrid enormities, is itself a frightful despotism. But this leads at length to a more formal and permanent despotism. The disorders and miseries, which result, gradually incline the minds of men to seek security and repose in the absolute power of an individual: and sooner or later the chief of some prevailing faction, more able or more fortunate than his competitors, turns this disposition to the purposes of his own elevation, on the ruins of Public Liberty. Without looking forward to an extremity of this kind (which nevertheless ought not to be entirely out of sight) the common and continual mischiefs of the spirit of party are sufficient to make it the interest and duty of a wise People to discourage and restrain it. It serves always to distract the public councils and enfeeble the Public Administration. It agitates the Community with ill-founded jealousies and false alarms; kindles the animosity of one part against another, foments occasionally riot and insurrection. It opens the door to foreign influence and corruption, which finds a facilitated access to the government itself through the channels of party passions. Thus the policy and the will of one country are subjected to the policy and will of another. There is an opinion that parties in free countries are useful checks upon the administration of the Government, and serve to keep alive the spirit of Liberty. This within certain limits is probably true; and in Governments of a monarchical cast, Patriotism may look with indulgence, if not with favor upon the spirit of party. But in those of the popular character, in Governments purely elective, it is a spirit not to be encouraged. From their natural tendency, it is certain there will always be enough of that spirit for every salutary purpose. And there being constant danger of excess, the effort ought to be, by force of public opinion, to mitigate and assuage it. A fire not to be quenched; it demands a uniform vigilance to prevent its bursting into a flame, lest, instead of warming it should consume. --G. Washington, 1796

item.title: Gift
item.description: We know constant plugs are annoying, but please try to take a different perspective here: Although millions of people read our comics every week, it's still difficult for creators to make a living. We don't get any money directly from Instagram or any other platform we post on. If we wouldn’t have a Patreon page, we’d have to get real jobs and couldn't make comics at all. So when you see plugs from us or any other artist, please be kind and remember we're just trying to keep creating. Thank you for understanding! https://www.patreon.com/warandpeas
item.dc:creator: Warandpeasofficial

item.title: I found my winter project, and it's the biggest goddamned cash register I've ever seen. Neigh for me.
item.description:
Soooo... hi guys! It's been a minute, huh? Heck, almost two months have passed since I wrapped up the most punishing restoration I've tried to tackle. So I thought, why not find one that's nice and easy? Something relaxing, uncomplicated, just a smooth disassemble, shine, and reassemble project? And then I found this monstrosity and decided the pain is fun. D: So yeah. This is my new project for winter: a massive, jammed up, brass and oak boat anchor that is easily the largest machine I've gotten my dirty clitbeaters on since finishing THIS massive thing almost a year ago to the day: https://i.imgur.com/RIbXkzl.jpeg I remember way back when, I told myself I'd do smaller registers. Easier ones. Oh, what a simple world I lived in. And oh god, what a mess I've gotten myself into now. :3
Anyhoo, about this register! It's huge, and it's heavy, and it needs a lot of work. There, that's all you get. :3 Nah, just joshing. In a bit more detail, this thing has spent a good bit of its life sitting in storage. When I saw it listed for sale, it was partly disassembled already by the seller who had wanted to get it working again but didn't have a clue what was wrong with it, or how to disassemble it to do the work. What I know right now is it is *thoroughly* jammed. Seriously, zero give on that handle. Also, notice how there's grass outside? That's because this thing spent a couple months camped out in my garage because I couldn't flippin' get anyone over to help me haul it the rest of the way into the house! It's not just heavy, it's irresponsibly heavy.
Don't mind the knee. Just be glad they're still intact. o_@ Once I got it inside with some help, I had to attach the receipt paper spool for the sake of posterity. The register's super dusty, but not really what I'd call dirty. At first blush I can tell there are several screws that never made the trip to my house, so I'll have some fun finding replacements come time for reassembly. The wood cash box is really dried out and has a texture like... well, like really dry wood. So some rehydrating will be in order later on. Something I really appreciate is the handle on the front of the drawer, and the divots that got gouged in by people constantly grabbing it and rubbing their fingertips against the grain. I like to look at details like that and just think for a while.
One of the first things that drew my interest to this machine is the weird printer box, and whatever its twin is on the opposite side (photo below). I'm used to seeing registers with just the one box, so I genuinely don't know yet which one is which and what the extra one is for. There's a lot of little features on this one that I'm utterly unfamiliar with, which is why I suspect this project will take me a while longer than usual to finish.
Of course, it wouldn't be a proper restoration if I didn't have to replace weirdly specific pieces of glass. I'm pretty sure this got broken during the drive to my house. Not a huge deal, maybe five bucks to replace, but still an extra trip. The handle to the right of it is something new to me, too. Something that got my attention really quick is just how rusty it is. It's not just surface rust either, it's had time to really cake up to the point that touching it lets loose a whole bunch of loose rust grit. That makes me think wherever this was stored, they didn't worry much about humidity.
Yet another opportunity to buy glass! :D Normally the details for how many transactions were rung up and which kind are hidden underneath a locked lid, so I'm a little surprised to see these not just plainly visible but apparently designed to be on display.
Nothing more reassuring than buying a register that comes with a bag of spare parts! I'm assuming some of the screws come from the case, but some are for these embellishments too.
I was a little worried when they handed me this wooden slat, but once I saw it had pin holes drilled into it and a lock, I knew it was meant to be removed. The one thing that worries me is there's damage where those pines are meant to slot in, so at some point someone physically tore this thing out. Probably because they lost the key. Dingbats. :/
It turns out to be a removable panel at the back of the cash box. Though why it needs to be removable at all, I wasn't sure. Nothing about this cash register is normal to me, but then again I've never worked on a 500 Series before. Just 300s and 400s. Even in 1911 they were just cranking out features to see what'd stick!
Also included with the register were a handful of slips the seller said they found in the drawer after they bought it. How they got the drawer open is beyond me, but part of me worries it has to do with that wooden backboard being partly damaged where the pins slot in. I thought they were pretty nifty since they purportedly come from the store the register was used in. I tried looking up "The Country Store" in Fairbank, IA to see if maybe it's still around or if I could learn something about it but I came up with nothing I'd consider concrete. Just some passing mentions of an Amish business by a similar name, and a lot of suggestions that "The Country Store" is as common as a place called "The General Store." More digging to do later.
You think they'd still honor this?
Anyhow, it's about time I stopped dickering and start taking things apart. My first instinct was to remove the breastplate because that's always what's had to come off first. Only...
This stupid thing is in the way! What is it? I still don't know for sure. "Things Wanted?" Was it common for clerks to jot down notes on what customers wanted but couldn't find? Is that how retail used to work??
Taking off the lid was simple enough, just yank. Inside it looks like a simple spool to spool roller. Paper goes on one side, slides over the steel plate for writing, and gets rolled up on the other side.
Sadly no treasures beneath it. Lots of dust though! You guys need any dust?
With the "Things Needed" box removed, I can take off the front. Now, you may be saying to yourself, "No fair, you cheated and took extra stuff off without showing it!" Oh, you innocent lambs. I thought it was that simple too.
Nope. That whole thing came off in one massive, single part. As far as I can tell it doesn't come apart and was just cast like this, or possibly tacked together in two steps. Cleaning and polishing this thing is going to be so much fuuuun... D:
Since I'm already a little out of sorts as to what should come off next, I end up having to spend time just looking over where the screws are and figuring out what'll hook into what panel if I take it off. Eventually I decide to take off the printer box because... well, it's meant to be detachable.
Easy enough. The receipt paper spool has to come off as well so they end up in the same boat. The paper is way too brittle to be usable, so it got set aside until the restoration is done to be used as a visual aide.
The handle comes off as well, mostly so I can get at those side panels later on. You might already notice that the printer mechanism doesn't look to be in great shape at all. The bronze number stamps are greened up, lots of rust, and you can peel the nickel plate off some of them like it's cellophane. Not good news, but we must move on.
I kind've like this handle design. The tube beside it just hides the interlock mechanism from view and is entirely decorative. The handle itself is severely rusted, so there's little chance of it shining up very well with so much nickel just gone.
Here's a closer look at the printer. Aside from the fact that it's just caked in dust, it's also severely corroded. What I'm afraid of is that this is likely what's jamming the register. Something in this mess of spools and gears is refusing to move, which means nothing moves. Since I don't have the first clue how to remove the printer, this is probably going to be where I spent the bulk of my time looking grumpy and a little constipated.
I do want to get this spool off and clean it. It's a custom stamp for the receipt and should have some information on it either from the business it was bought for, or just some cool history to enjoy. Unfortunately for right now, it's on there good. Even sticking a block of wood against it and whacking it with a hammer didn't make it budge. So either it's rusted on, or I don't understand what keeps it in place.
It took me a while to figure out how to get this panel off. Some of the printer was in the way and had to be taken apart to get enough clearance, which is what you see in the middle there. Finding a cotter pin in an inch of dust is super fun, I suggest all of you try it right now go GO GO GO
But yeaaah... those drive gears do not look good, either. Now that they're exposed, I can appreciate just how damp it was where this spent most of its life. Normally those wheels are greased up really well so I don't know what happened here. That's way too much rust. Like... that's a shitload of rust. We're going to run to the other side where I can pretend this is still an easy project. D:
Alrighty, so this one's weird. Usually the side panels both screw into the rear panel. On this register, only the right side does that and this left side has the screws threading into *it.* So I've gotta take the back off *before* I take the sides off. And with so much clearance! Seriously, this register is so heavy that I don't trust pivoting it without this bench taking a stage dive to the ground. I'll take awkward over suicidal.
Bingo bango bongo, that was easy. :D A little green death on the brass but not so much that I'm worried. Plus that rear glass is intact! Woo!
Even more good news, the original marble is fully intact and just dirty! I can clean that off easy, hah!
Awww yeah, now that's some super dry and crusty oak! Definitely going to need to refinish the top of this box. Also, no treasures hidden behind it. Damn cashiers being careful and stuff.
Before we get too far, here's a quick look at how absolutely locked up this thing is. Barely a single button moves. The lever is absolutely seized. And the reset lever on the bottom doesn't do diddly because the register is still stuck halfway through a cycle. So... yeah, I'm going to need to invest in penetrating oil and open some windows.
As with any project, it's time to take the top off. Badum-tss. ;)
I can see into your head! OwO
And now I can pull off the upper plate to reveal the total counter, which is strategically covered up by a steel slider that only a key can retract! Finally, I actually have that stupid key, too! Hooohoo!
Also, pardon the weirdly widescreen photos. This new phone has weird aspect ratios and I have no idea how to fix it yet. Look at all that empty wood! :o
Also, for the curious, this is how I date these registers. The serial number lines up with a manufacturing window in 1911, which I can usually confirm by flipping over the cash drawer and looking at the sticker glued underneath. Right now I can't get the drawer open because *gestures vaguely* it be jammin, mon. The 552 is the model number, which I'll have to do more digging on later. Lots of things to look into later. Hooboy.
And finally, with all the panels yanked off, this big hunk of metal is free to come off. Notice how there's no chute for paper to come out, just a window. I definitely don't have enough retail experience because I don't know what the hell this was actually for.
And I DEFINITELY don't recognize whatever this mechanism was intended to be. Judging by the spools and that glass window, it was a printer as well, but why would you print anything that didn't spit out paper? And why was this so ungodly large? EVEN MORE TO INVESTIGATE. AUGH!
Yeah, this side isn't giving me any clues either. Why the weird box at the top? And so many cams? Does one printer need this many cams?
As for right now... I gotta do some serious research and spend a lot more time poking around this thing. I'll say one thing right now, there's no way I'm taking this apart like I did that last register. This is an order of magnitude more complex and I don't even dare attempt to pull it apart. I've already spent a fair bit of time banging around with the guts to see how well it lines up with the last crank register I restored, and right now I'm not seeing anything in the main body that's jammed or refuses to move. Not only that but the bulk of the internals are pretty free of rust, which tells me they still have their grease.
I even flipped this around now that there's a bit of weight off, and I'm not seeing anything inside that screams "problem." Everything is mobile, so my guess is the problem is somewhere in that rusty bitch of a printer. God help me, that's going to be a challenge to fix.
Also, check this out! This is where that back panel goes, and the bell is right there inside the cash box! I've never once seen a drawer mechanism like this, so count me excited to learn more! Normally at this point I would try to lift off the mechanism and put it up on a pair of wooden chocks on the desk to work on separately, but I can't get this stupid thing off the box because the drawer release is designed in a way that I *can't* unless the register is completely cycled. I don't know how easy it is to tell, but see that vertical post down the middle? That's the release. In past experience, this is just a chisel tip that goes up and down and pushes on a latch attached to the drawer. For this register, it doesn't go up and down. It flipping rotates.
Better yet, it has these weird collars screwed around it at the top and bottom? It's these collars that are in the way when I try to lift the mechanism off the box, and right now I'm not 100% sure I can unscrew them without borking something up. So... add that to the incredibly long list of stuff I don't understand yet but eventually will.
Of course, there has to be an obligatory close-up of the buttons. Right now, this $10 key is completely rusted in place. I can't pull it free, push it the rest of the way down, nothing. This thing has been like that for yeeeaars and does not give a shit about things like leverage or muscle. I'll come back to you, you rusty devil.
And of course there's this... uh... mechanism. I haven't the first idea what this handle and lock assortment is supposed to do, which seems to be the running theme for this restoration! Best I can tell, and this is just a guess because literally none of it functions, is that the locks can be turned to keep certain clerk keys (A, B, D, and E) from being selected. I know those clerk keys have to be pressed down to perform a transaction, which "D" is very much rusted into position, but what purpose the lever serves is beyond me. So... MORE RESEARCH. *sobs in unenlightenment*
Naturally, the logical step is to take the confusing locks off in hopes they reveal their secrets. Which they don't.
Naturally, the logical step is to take the entire damned mounting block off in hopes it reveal its secrets. Fuck. I'm still confused.
Naturally, the logical step is to TAKE A BREAK AND RECUPERATE. Yeah, that's the ticket! We're hitting pause! I have so much homework to do that I don't know where to start, so I'll probably just pick my top three things and do them all at once. Because that's how my brain works, and when has my brain ever been wrong?
In all seriousness, I definitely have a lot of work ahead of me before I can fully appreciate half of what I'm looking at. I'm genuinely excited to come across this many questions on one machine! For a while I was starting to worry I'd seen pretty much all that these registers had to offer in terms of features, and suddenly I'm sitting on a good dozen or so questions I get to dig out the answers for! This restoration is going to take a bit of time, so I hope you'll all bear with me as I share updates that are probably less geared toward "Hey, I did one massive job all at once!" and more toward, "I figured out a few more features and have history to share!" If you're up for it and feel like helping out, most of my projects have been made possible through donations toward the restoration fund! I love that so many of you get excited to learn about these antiques and see how they turn out, and my Kofi is always open should you like to chip in some support: https://ko-fi.com/elbowdeepinahorse Until the next update! Wish me luck!
